title-group.article-title: The Impact of Foot Insole on the Energy Consumption of Flat-Footed Individuals During Walking

contrib-group.aff: Musculoskeletal Research Centre, Rehabilitation Faculty of Isfahan University of Medical Sciences, Isfahan, Islamic Republic of Iran

author-notes.corresp: Mohammad Taghi Karimi, Isfahan Medical University, Isfahan, Iran, Isfahan, 12345678, Islamic Republic of Iran.

abstract.p: Background. The human foot contains one of the most variable structures of the body, which is the medial longitudinal arch. Decrease in the height of this arch results in a flat foot. Although there is some evidence regarding the influence of flat foot on gait performance of flat-footed individuals, there is no strong evidence to support the theory that being flat-footed has an effect on energy consumption. Therefore, the aim of this study was to find the relationship between flat foot and energy consumption. Method. Two groups of normal and flat-footed participants were recruited in this research project. They were selected from the staff and students of Isfahan University of Medical Sciences. The foot indexes of both groups were obtained using the footprint method with help of Solid worker software. The physiological cost index (PCI) of the participants was measured by the use of a heart rate monitoring system (Polar Electro, Finland). The differences between the PCIs of both groups of participants was determined using a t test. In addition, the influence of using an insole was evaluated using a paired t test. Result. The energy consumption of flat-footed individuals differed significantly from that of normal individuals (the PCIs of normal and flat-footed individuals were 0.357 and 0.368 beats/m, respectively). Using a foot insole improved the performance of the flat-footed individuals during walking. Conclusion. The PCI of flat-footed individuals is more than that of normal participants as a result of misalignment of foot structure. Moreover, using a foot insole improved foot alignment and decreased energy consumption.
Levels of Evidence: Therapeutic, Level III: comparative case series

disp-quote.p: “Recent biomechanical studies have shown that an orthosis insole improves the arch alignment, increases the duration of the stance phase while walking on level surfaces, and reduces the angular deformities of the leg resulting from flat-foot disorder.”

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The human foot exhibits a wide range of structural variation that is seen in many parts of the body. One of the most important and most variable structural characteristics of the foot is the height of the medial longitudinal arch (MLA) relative to the ground plane.1 Decrease in the height of the MLA is known as a flat foot. It has been described as a loss of the MLA of the foot, valgus deformity of the head, and medial talar prominence. Although several factors contribute to the etiology of flat foot, the most important ones are ligamentous laxity, tibial torsional deformity, presence of accessory navicular bone, congenital vertical talus, and tarsal coalition.2-9

The prevalence of flat foot varies between 0.69% and 28% depending on the age group.10-12 The prevalence of flat foot in Arab countries was 5%, compared with 0.69% in adolescent boys in the Turkish population.13 Flat feet can lead to many unpleasant problems, including heel pain, bunions, hammer toes, shin splints, and even knee, hip, or back pain.6,14-16

Various types of foot orthoses have been used to support the longitudinal arch of the foot and to decrease the problems associated with flat-foot disorder.16-18 Recent biomechanical studies have shown that an orthosis insole improves the arch alignment, increases the duration of the stance phase while walking on level surfaces, and reduces the angular deformities of the leg resulting from flat-foot disorder.17,19 The difference between the gait performance of those who suffer from flat foot and that of normal individuals has been studied in various research projects.19,20 It has been shown that compared with a normal foot, a flat foot exhibits both a higher plantarflexion ankle moment and angle.19

Moreover, there is some evidence that pronated foot posture is related to greater EMG amplitude of invertor muscles such as the tibialis posterior and lower EMG amplitude of evertor muscles such as the proneus longus, when compared with a normal or supinated foot.21

A look at the relevant literature shows that there is not enough evidence regarding the influence of flat foot on energy consumption during walking. Moreover, it is not clear whether wearing an insole influences the energy consumption or not. The only research study in this regard was by Otman.22 It has been shown that using an insole decreases the energy consumption based on oximetry. However, this was not done in a standard way. Therefore, the aim of this research was to find the difference in energy consumption between normal and flat-footed individuals and to evaluate the influence of using a customary insole on energy consumption while walking.

sec.title: Method
sec.p: Two groups of 25 normal and flat-footed individuals participated in this research project. The participants were recruited from among the students of Isfahan University of Medical Sciences who were living in university housing (accommodation for women). They were selected based on the flat-foot indices obtained during standing. The flat-foot indices of the participants while standing (static position) and during walking (dynamic position) were measured based on the footprint method.23-26 The characteristics of those who participated in this research study are shown in Table 1. Ethical approval was obtained from the Isfahan University of Medical Sciences Ethical Approval Committee. A consent form was also received from each participant before data collection.

caption.p: Characteristics of Those Who Participated in This Research Study

sec.title: Procedure
sec.p: Participants were instructed about the testing procedure and the instruments, and then, their weight and height were measured and recorded. In the next stage, the flat foot indices of the participants were measured in the static and dynamic conditions. To obtain footprints, the sole of the participant’s foot was painted with finger colors. The participant remained seated in front of the platform. With the aid of an investigator, the participants placed their foot on the rolled paper with the contralateral foot out of the platform (the participant was asked to apply half of their body weight on the examined foot). The same procedure was repeated for the contralateral side. The mean value of the right- and left-side indices was used for the find analysis. The participants were divided into normal and flat-footed groups according to footprint index data, as is shown in Table 2.

caption.p: Mean Values of the Footprint Indices Used to Distinguish the Flat-Footed From Normal Participants

sec.p: In the next stage, the participant was asked to walk on a rolled out sheet of paper with the painted foot. To evaluate severity of the flat foot, some parameters such as arch index and footprint angle were selected. The prints of the foot in the static and dynamic conditions were scanned and used as the input for the Solid worker software. The value of the aforementioned parameters was calculated using the software (Figure 1). The validity and repeatability of this method was found to be more than 0.95 (P value = .00).

caption.p: Determination of Arch Index (A) and Footprint Angle (B) Using Solid Worker Software.

sec.p: To determine the amount of energy consumption during walking of normal and flat-footed individuals (with and without insole), heart rate monitoring was used. The heart rate, during resting and walking, and walking speed were the parameters used for evaluation of energy consumption based on the physiological cost index (PCI). It is determined according to the following equation27:

It has been shown that heart rate is an accurate estimation of oxygen consumption and is a simple and easy to use parameter in any condition. There is a highly positive relationship between heart rate and energy and oxygen consumption. The correlation between heart rate, PCI, and total heart beat (THB) during comfortable walking was reported to be more than 0.98 for normal participants. The main reason to select these parameter to represent energy consumption was that they had a high correlation with an oxygen consumption–based parameter. It has been shown that within-day test-retest of PCI is excellent among healthy and handicapped participants in terms of intraclass correlation and is acceptable in terms of agreement.28 It has been used in most clinical studies to determine the performance of participants based on energy expenditure and also to evaluate the influence of orthotic interventions. This parameter can be used to estimate energy cost, which can be done in a clinical setting.28-30

For the energy consumption test, a Polar heart rate monitor was used (Polar Company, Finland). This system, also called Polar Electro Finland, consists of a transmitter embedded in an electrode belt. The receiver and recorder are located in a specially designed wrist watch. The belt has 2 electrodes that are covered by a special rubber and is worn around the chest below the nipple line. The collected heart rate was transmitted to the watch with the help of electromagnetic waves. The accuracy of this system in collecting the heart rate is claimed to be ±1 beats per minute. A 22.04-m tract in the form of an 8-shaped figure was measured out in the lab. Walking along this figure enables the participants to have a steady walking speed during walking. Moreover, the effect of the dominant limb would be diminished. The participants were asked not to eat or drink coffee or tea at least 2 hours before the test. The lower limit of heart rate was set at 40 beats/min, and the data were collected at 5-s intervals. The test was done according to the following procedure:

list-item.p: Heart rate monitor worn by participant
Five minutes’ resting heart rate collected
Standing up and then remaining in this position for 2 minutes
Ten minutes walking with a self-selected walking speed
Five minutes of resting during which data were collected

sec.p: The mean value of the heart rate from the 1st to 4th minutes and from the 17th to 21st minutes was used for measuring the resting heart rate. The mean value of heart rate during walking was obtained by averaging the heart rate between the 4th and 7th minutes of walking.

The arch support used in this research project was made specifically according to the size of the participants’ feet. They were manufactured from leather and polyethylene foam, with a moderate density, according to the standard method of fabrication used for this (Figure 2).31

caption.p: The Arch Support Used in This Research Project.

sec.p: The normal distribution of the parameters was measured using a Shapiro-Wilk test (with a significance level of .05). Because the parameters had a normal distribution, the parametric test was used for the final analysis. The difference between the mean values of PCI, footprint indices, and THB of normal and flat-footed individuals were measured using the 2-sample t test. The correlation between foot indices and amount of energy consumption, based on PCI and THB indices, was evaluated using Pearson correlation.

sec.title: Result
sec.p: The mean values of the flat-foot indices in the static and dynamic conditions for normal and flat-footed individuals are shown in Table 3, and a significant difference between normal and flat-footed individuals can be seen. It can be seen from Table 4 that the mean value of energy consumption based on the PCI of the flat-footed individuals was 0.368, compared with 0.357 beats/m for normal participants (P value of the difference was .0393). The THB parameter, which is the number of heart beats during walking with respect to distance walk, was another parameter used in this study. It was 1.58 and 1.6 beats/m for normal and flat-footed individuals, respectively (Table 4).

caption.p: Characteristics of Normal and Flat-Footed Participants
Walking Speed, PCI, and THB of Flat-Footed Participants Walking With and Without Insole and Also of Normal Participants

fn.p: Abbreviations: PCI, physiological cost index; THB, total heart beat.

sec.p: The mean values of walking speed of normal and flat-footed individuals differed, but the difference was not significant. Using a foot insole improved the walking speed significantly (67.43 ± 1024 and 69.14 ± 11.43 m/min, for walking with and without insole, respectively). As can be seen from Table 4, using a foot insole decreased the energy consumption indices significantly (P < .05).

The relationship between the foot indices of the flat-footed individuals and the magnitude of energy consumption was assessed using Pearson correlation. The Pearson correlations between arch index and PCI, and arch index and THB are 0.494 and 0.463, respectively, with P <.05 (Table 5).

caption.p: Correlation Between Foot Indices and Energy Consumption While Walking

fn.p: Abbreviations: PCI, physiological cost index; THB, total heart beat.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Flat foot is described as the loss of the MLA of the foot, valgus deformity of the head, and medial talar prominence.5,8,11 Unfortunately, there is not enough evidence to show the effect of flat foot on energy consumption while walking. Moreover, the effect of using an insole on the walking performance of the participants is not clear. Therefore, the aim of this study was to find the difference between the energy consumption of flat-footed and normal individuals.

In this research study, the normal and flat-footed individuals were recruited from a female group. However, the selection of the participants from among women does not represent any bias because the difference between the PCIs of the participants while walking with and without an insole was measured in this study. Furthermore, the normal participants were also women in this study. Finally, it is important to note that there is no significant difference between the kinetic and kinematic parameters of male and female individuals while walking on a level surface. Therefore, it can be concluded that the external validity of the results of this study is high and can be used for all individuals (male and female).

According to the results of this research shown in Table 2, the PCI and THB of the flat-footed individuals were more than those of normal participants in level walking. It has been found in biomechanical studies that the gait parameters of normal and flat-footed individuals vary from each other. Hunt and Smith19 showed that compared with a normal foot, a flat foot exhibits both a higher plantar flexion angle in the stance phase of walking and a greater peak of plantar flexion ankle moment. Moreover, there is some evidence that a pronated foot posture is associated with greater EMG amplitude for invertor muscles, such as the tibialis posterior, compared with that for a normal foot.32 Additionally, as the loads applied on ligamentus structures of the flat-footed individuals is more than that of normal participants, the greater loading of the MLA may involve greater work from the tibialis posterior to protect the arch. Therefore, the magnitude of energy consumption of flat-footed individuals is more than that of normal individuals as a result of overuse of the leg muscles.19,20,32

Using an insole improves the gait efficiency of flat-footed individuals and decreases the PCI significantly. It also realigns the skeletal structure of the foot and alters the moment pattern of the lower extremity during gait. It has been shown that using arch support helps the tibialis posterior in reducing the pronation of the foot. The influence of arch support on the motion and moment of the ankle and knee joints is the other important consideration in this regard.19-21,33

The energy consumption of flat-footed individuals with an insole was less than that of normal participants during level walking. There is no doubt that the structure of the arch of the foot is maintained during single-limb support with the help of the tibialis posterior muscle. Using arch support decreases the collapse of the arch and indirectly decreases the activity of this muscle. Therefore, the energy consumption decreases while walking.32

To the author’s knowledge, there are limited numbers of studies regarding the performance of flat-footed individuals based on energy consumption. Results of the study by Otman et al22 showed that the energy consumption (based on oxygen measurement) decreased in patients with flat feet following the use of a suitable arch support. However, the resting heart rates, blood pressure, and oxygen consumption values did not show a significant difference between normal and flat-footed individuals. It is important to note that the heart rate (which was used as the main parameter in the study by Otman et al) is influenced by some environmental and physiological parameters. Therefore, it cannot be used to represent the efficiency of an orthosis while walking.34

As can be seen from Table 4, there is a significant correlation between the magnitude of energy consumption and flat-foot severity (based on the arch index), which represents overactivity of the supporting muscles of the MLA in this group of patients. It can be concluded that a high flat-foot index is associated with high energy consumption.

There are some limitations that need to be acknowledged in this research study. These include the follow-up period, which was too limited, and the number of participants, which was small. Therefore, it is recommended that a similar study be done on a larger number of participants. Moreover, it is recommended that the PCI is noted after a period of follow-up using the same procedure.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The results of this research showed that there is considerable difference between the PCIs of normal and flat-footed individuals because of structural misalignment of the foot. Using an arch support aligns the structure of the foot and decreases the energy consumption during walking.

fn.label: Author Note
fn.p: The author of this research study would like to acknowledge all individuals who kindly participated in this study.
